I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  Macroeconomic context. Bangladesh has achieved more than 6.0% annual economic 
growth since 2011 and has recorded 7.9% in FY2018. The country’s economy is expected to grow 
by  8%  in  2019  and  2020.1 Such  strong  growth  is  fueled  by  expansion  in  export-oriented 
manufacturing including ready-made garments, light engineering, shipbuilding, agribusiness, 
information and communication technology (ICT) and pharmaceuticals.2 Expansion of these and 
other emerging sectors requires high skilled professionals who can effectively manage technical 
and organizational developments. Bangladesh workforce also needs diverse and adaptable skills 
to face the rapid changes in technologies.  
 
2.  Education sector performance. The government has made continuous investments in 
education, especially in promoting equitable access, enabling Bangladesh to achieve education-
related Millennial Development Goals before 2015. Currently, almost all children go to primary 
schools, while two out of three children are enrolled in secondary education. Enrollment of girls 
exceeds that of boys in all levels of education, except for tertiary level. Tertiary education 
enrollment has grown from 13.9% in 2014 to is 20.6% in 2018 (17.0% females and 24.0% males). 
These are still lower than the low middle income country average of 24.8% (25.4% female and 
24.3% male).3 With 1.3 million youth joining the labor market every year, turning the increasing 
working population into skilled and productive human resources is a paramount agenda to the 
government. 
 
3.  Role of tertiary education. Tertiary education is critical for a country’s socioeconomic 
development in (i) producing high skilled workforce to drive innovation and to adapt to new 
technologies, (ii) providing up-skilling and re-skilling opportunities for existing workforce, and (iii) 
increasing qualified professionals for teaching positions to improve overall education quality, etc.4 
 
4.  Increasing demand for tertiary education. Increasing demand for tertiary education, 
especially university level higher education, is evident, based on the demographic structure and 
strong economic growth forecast. The gross enrollment rate was 17.6% in 2017, and the total 
higher education enrollment was estimated at 3.3 million in 2016, which is expected to rise to 
4.6 million in 2026 as the population grows. Access to higher education has been improved by 
the increase in private universities operating under the Private University Act, 1992 (amended in 
2010). Education quality and accountability vary widely in private universities, however, which 
needs to be addressed through close supervision while respecting the autonomy of the private 
universities.  
 
5.  Issues in quality and relevance. Teaching and learning and assessments in tertiary 
education are focused on absorption of knowledge and information and do not encourage critical

thinking or creativity. Outdated or knowledge-overloaded curricular, lecture-based pedagogy, high 
student-faculty ratios, and obelete and inadequate facilities constrain tertiary education quality. 
The relevance of higher education to the job market needs strengthening. Employers emphasize 
soft skills such as critical thinking, problem solving, communication, and collaboration in addition 
to academic knowledge, but these qualities are lacking among university graduates. Only one-
third of employers maintain sustained partnerships with universities, mainly for recruitment.5 
Research and development activities are limited due to lack of funding and research personnel, 
and mostly driven by academic interests, with little relevance to industry needs.  
 
6.  Asian Development Bank’s Assistance. Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been a 
long-term partner in education sector development in Bangladesh, especially in school education 
and skills development. ADB currently supports primary and secondary education sector-wide 
approaches with emphasis on Science, Mathematics, English, and use of ICT. ADB is assisting 
the government in expanding job-relevant training opportunities focusing on basic to mid-level 
skills linked with job placements through industry partnerships. Since 2018, the government has 
requested several interventions in tertiary education development.6  
 
7.  Building upon the achievements of past and ongoing education sector projects as well as 
lessons from recent engagement in tertiary education, ADB will help the government make 
strategic investments for the subsector catering to specific industries’ demand for improved 
human capital and contribute to socioeconomic transformation. Lessons from the preparatory 
work for the Improving Computer and Software Engineering Tertiary Education Project are (i) that 
wider stakeholder consultants (especially with industry and students) are crucial to inform the 
project design and convince universities and the government to adopt innovative approaches, 
and (ii) that quality and relevance improvement measures require several rounds of discussion to 
gather momentum for institution-wide buy-in. A technical assistance providing strategic technical 
inputs through resource persons and expert consultants has been highly appreciated by the 
government and stakeholders as the technical areas require understanding of latest industry 
requirements, international good practices, and innovative approaches proven successful in other 
countries. ADB will focus its efforts in specific disciplines or universities to provide integrated 
supports in developing new and upgraded higher education programs, addressing the gaps in 
quality and relevance of those programs. This approach complements the World Bank’s higher 
education  interventions  aiming  at  improving  university  governance,  quality  assurance,  and 
research capacity across the whole sub-sector.  
 
8.  Rationale for a transaction technical assistance facility. The transaction TA facility will 
provide  project  preparation  support  and  capacity  building  to  a  series  of  ensuing  projects, 
comprising (i) Improving Computer and Software Engineering Tertiary Education Project (for 
commitment in 2020), (ii) Digital University Development Project (2020), (iii) Innovations in 
Tertiary  Education  for  Competitiveness  (Advanced  Agriculture)  Project  (2021),  and  (iv) 
Innovations in Tertiary Education for Competitiveness (Garments and Textiles) Project (2022).7 
All ensuing projects are in the tertiary education subsector, where the Ministry of Education, the 
University  Grants  Commissions,  relevant  universities,  and  industry  partners  will  be  key 
stakeholders in project design and implementation. The project preparation will require similar set 
of due diligence in technical, safeguard, poverty, social, gender, fiduciary management and 
economic assessment. Using a TA facility is suitable as it will enhance project preparation

B.  Outline of the Terms of Reference for Consultants 
 
1.  The TRTA will assess the university proposals and conduct studies, surveys and due 
diligence through firm and individual consultant contracts as follows. 
 
1.  Firms  
 
(1)  Fiduciary Review Firm (National) 
 
2.  A firm will be engaged to conduct an independent fiduciary review of the project including 
operational and financial aspects of the implementation. The independent fiduciary review will 
propose  measures  to  improve  the  efficacy  of  internal  control  arrangements  and  project 
performance against project objectives.

3.  Financial  management  specialist/Team  leader  (national,  4  person-months).  The 
specialist are preferred to have at least a graduate degree in financial management or be certified 
accountants and have at least 15 years of relevant working experience, preferably in government-
executed  donor-funded  projects,  as  accountants  in  Bangladesh.  Experience  with  financial 
management reviews in accordance with the guidelines from multilateral organizations is highly

design,  management,  and  implementation  of  surveys;  demonstrate  team  leadership, 
organizational, communication, relational, and report writing skills; and having an excellent 
command of the English language will be an advantage. 
 
4.  Procurement specialist (national, 3 person-months). The specialist are preferred to have 
at least graduate degrees in engineering, public administration, business administration, or other 
related disciplines and at least 10 years’ experience in public procurement and capacity building 
in procurement. Experience working with procurement guidelines from multilateral organizations 
in relation to the national government’s procurement guidelines is highly preferred. 
 
(2)  Tracer Study and Employer Survey Firm (National) 
 
5.  A firm will be engaged to conduct data collection survey on tracer study and employer 
survey. The data collection includes both quantitative (tracer study and employer survey) and 
qualitative (focus group discussions and key informant interviews) data. 
 
(i)  Employer survey: The employer survey will be administered to approximately 
1,000 firms in Bangladesh. The questionnaire-based interview is expected to last 
approximately 60 minutes per firm. The data will be collected through computer 
assisted personal interview (CAPI) using approximately 20 tablets (depending on 
the number of enumerators, the number of tablets is subject to change) to reduce 
data entry time and mistakes as well as check the accuracy of data quality in real 
time during survey. 
(ii)  Tracer  study:  The  tracer  study  will  be  administered to  1200  graduates  from 
selected  universities  in  Bangladesh.  The  questionnaire-based  interview  is 
expected to last approximately 20 minutes per person. The data will be collected 
through computer assisted telephone interview (CATI). 
(iii)  Qualitative Survey: The focus group discussions (FGD) will cover 36 groups and 
each group is consisted of approximately 8 people. The group will be formed by 
gender,  teacher/student,  graduates  (employed,  unemployed).  Each  FGD  is 
expected to last approximately 1.5 hour. The FGD will be recorded, and all of the 
discussions will be transcribed for detailed qualitative analysis. The qualitative 
survey also includes key informant interviews with key stakeholders. 
 
6.  Quantitative Survey Expert/Team Leader (national, 3 person-months). The team leader 
is preferred to have a Master’s degree in education, development studies, statistics, social 
sciences, computer science, information technology or similar, with at least 5 years of experience 
managing large-scale field-based quantitative data collection in socio-economic field. Having 5 
years of proven experience with data quality assurance mechanism (field work management, data 
entry programming etc.) will be an advantage. The team leader is preferred to have proven ability 
to  communicate  with  different  stakeholders  in  local  language,  including  university  officials, 
government, and industry experts, and experience of qualitative surveys and electronic data 
collection  platforms.  Having  demonstrated  ability  to  deploy  surveys  in  multiple  locations, 
particularly related to information technology surveys, as well as excellent report writing and 
communication skills in English will be an advantage.

I.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
1.  Bangladesh achieved more than 6% annual economic growth since 2011 and recorded 
7.9% economic growth in FY2018. The stable economic growth has been driven by ready-made 
garment sector export, strong consumption, and public investment. Sustaining economic growth 
requires diversifying the economic base and creating new sources of growth. Digital Bangladesh 
is an integral part of national development strategy since 2010 and the government expects 
information technology (IT) industry to make significant contribution to the economy.1 IT sector 
development will generate new growth opportunities, creating large number of jobs, increase 
economy-wide productivity, and improve service delivery through e-government initiatives.  
 
2.  Bangladesh IT industry and human resource constraints. Bangladesh’s IT industry is 
in nascent stage of development, with two thirds of firms established after 2000. Most of the firms 
are small, with around 95% having less than 100 personnel. They are mostly engaged in the lower 
end of the value chain. The industry faces several challenges among which lack of skilled human 
resource is the most critical constraint. With increasing push for cost competitiveness and advent 
of Industrial Revolution 4.0, IT industry is facing enormous opportunities and challenges globally. 
Companies across world are increasing focus on research and development (R&D), speed of 
execution, product quality and services. Search for new-age skills such as machine learning 
engineers, application development analysts, back-end developers, data scientists, as well as 
upskilling and reskilling existing personnel are the top priorities for the industry. Annually, the 
industry hires around 15,000 people where one third are computer science and engineering and 
IT (CSE/IT) degree holders.2 Many universities offer CSE/IT degree programs producing around 
12,000 graduates every year, but with large variance in competencies and readiness for job. 
Overall, quality of new entrants is inadequate. Over 80% of job seekers fail in written test on basic 
coding skills, mathematics, and English. For mid-level skills such as testing, business analysis, 
and project management, the industry cannot find domestic talent and hires from neighboring 
countries at higher wages. This undermines business profitability and limits domestic talent pool. 
 
3.  Limited access to quality CSE/IT programs. Absolute number of CSE/IT program seats 
may seem enough, but access to quality programs is limited as evidenced by inadequate talent 
pool for the industry.3 Currently, technological changes outpace existing CSE/IT programs. 
Introducing new curricula is also constrained by lack of physical facilities, especially purpose-fit 
laboratories. Hands-on practical sessions are critical for core technical competencies such as 
problem-solving skills and use of IT equipment and applications, but practical sessions constitute 
less than 30% in public universities. This is even less in private universities (footnote 2). Even the 
limited laboratory time is not effective as laboratories are often in poorly equipped or maintained.4

While  many  universities  and  training  providers  offer  short  term  courses  for  immediate  job

upskilling to keep the pace with the technological advances and global business practices. There

4.  Outdated teaching and learning practices and limited research capacity. A strong 
faculty is the backbone of academic and research work in universities. Current teaching practices 
are teacher-centric and theory-focused, and assessment is largely examination-based. Changing 
the curriculum is largely constrained by rigid academic governance practices. Increasing number 
of faculty members have higher qualification such as Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.), but faculty 
members lack exposure to industry practices and technology trend. Faculty members have few 
opportunities in improving pedagogic skills and adopting modern approaches in technology 
education. R&D activities in university are limited due to lack of funding, little incentives for faculty 
and students, inadequate number of post-graduate students. Together with faculty capacity, post-
graduate programs are important to supply technology leaderships, carry out R&D for innovative 
technology solutions, and nurture future faculty. However, a high proportion of post graduate 
students drop out to take immediate jobs forgoing higher wage in the future when they obtain 
postgraduate degree.  
 
5.  Low relevance of CSE/IT education to industry demand. While some industry partners 
are involved in curriculum design and course delivery, overall, industry relevance of CSE/IT 
education needs urgent improvement. Students are poorly informed on industry requirements. 
Few universities have internship programs. Assessments are mostly about knowledge. Soft skills 
such as collaboration, communications, analytical thinking, and creativity are not given priority 
though  employers  cite  them  as  important.5 University  R&D  activities  are  driven  by  faculty 
members’ academic interest and do not reflect industry interest or provide solution to industry 
problems. Interdisciplinary R&D should be emphasized to encourage innovative IT solutions for 
management, medicine, manufacturing, infrastructure development, environment, and various 
services. Globally, universities became hub for technology startups leveraging knowledge and 
talents of university personnel with strong industry linkages. However, Bangladesh universities 
lack resources, knowhow and industry linkages to support startups.  
 
6.  Women in CSE/IT education and IT industry. While gender parity has been met in 
primary and secondary education, only 31% of university enrollment is women. As in other 
countries, fewer female students are enrolled in technology areas in Bangladesh due to gender 
stereotyping. In addition, the industry jobs requiring odd working hours and late stays discourage 
female students and workers from pursuing CSE/IT programs or industry careers. In public 
university CSE/IT programs, female students are 22%, but in IT industry, 19% of entry level 
workers are women. This ratio drops to 16% of overall human resource indicating low retention 
rate and career progression among female workers (footnote 2).

technology  entrepreneurship  to  respond  to  increasing  demand  and  changing  priorities  of

in quality, aligned with international standards for practicing engineers, even after the project is 
ended. The project will ensure adequate number of qualified faculty members to deliver quality 
education programs and carry out and guide research projects. The universities will expand 
reskilling and upskilling programs for IT professionals developed in collaboration with industry 
partners, aiming at continuous professional development at par with fast changing technologies.

Bangladesh’s aspiration to realize Digital Bangladesh needs to be bolstered by innovations through quality and

than 500,000 freelancers are engaged in low-end services. The job opportunities are concentrated in urban areas, 
and people from rural areas have very limited access to CSE/IT education and IT sector job opportunities.  
 
The proposed project will address (i) access, (ii) quality, (iii) relevance of CSE and IT education as well as lack of

implementation period. Private and public employers, more specifically the IT/ITES companies, will benefit from 
recruitments of more qualified graduates. Research and innovation activities in CSE/IT departments will also 
contribute to improve IT/ITES industry competitiveness. The proposed project will expand the foundation of skilled 
workers in formal sector through tertiary education, professional certificate courses as well as start-up support in 
urban area as well as rural area in Jessore where Sheikh Hasina Software Park is established by the government

1. What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project or program?  
While enrollment figures are higher for girls than boys in primary and secondary education, female enrollment for 
the higher education is considerably lower than males in 2017 (14.5% for female and 20.6% for male) and only 31%

participation in higher education, particularly related to advanced science and technology fields, needs to be 
reduced. In CSE/IIT related faculties, female students only account for around 22%, and addressing gender 
stereotyping remains a significant challenge. From employment perspectives, although the country’s unemployment 
rate has been stable around 4.2% in the last few years, youth unemployment rate (age 15–24) has continuously 
increased since 2010, reaching 12.3% in 2016. The unemployment rate with tertiary education background (overall: 
11.2%, male: 8.3%, female: 21.4%) is more than twice than overall unemployment rate, and transition from higher 
education to labor market needs further improvement, particularly for females. The female unemployment rate is 
around 6.7% in 2016, which is consistently higher than that of males (3.1%). Lower female labor force participation

compared with other lower middle-income countries. Informal economy, female child marriage, skills mismatch, 
access to finance and disparities in wages, among others, are hindrance to increase female labor force participation. 
In addition, in public university CSE/IT programs, female students are 25%, but in IT/ITES industry, 19% of entry 
level workers are women. This ratio drops to 16% of overall human resource indicating low retention rate and career
